1. Prescriptive thermal standards adopted in 2010 defining minimum mandatory U-values for the building envelope, corresponding to the average annual heat demand of 60 kWh/m2 for space heating of typical multi-apartment buildings and 120-130 kWh /m2 together with sanitary hot water preparation. 2. 1. The level is still the same as for the baseline. Although the Project helped formulate and draft new technical norms establishing building energy performance below 60 kWh/m2 per year (space heating and hot water supply), which were adopted, but these norms are not required by law. The Technical Code "Energy Efficiency of Buildings" (a law status), which was initiated and drafted by the Project, has been already passed the conciliation procedure and submitted to the Council of Ministers for adoption. It is expected that the Code will come into force in the beginning of 2017. The energy performance certification scheme has been also developed. The related article has been integrated in the said Technical Code. 2. In average, more than 50 experts from each of three professional groups (designers, construction inspectors, builders and policy-makers) have passed related courses including two practical courses with the Minsk pilot construction site visits for construction engineers. There are already 7 local design institutes (NIPTIS, MAPID, Hrodnagrazhdanproekt, Gomelgrazhdanproekt, Saint-Gobain Construction Product BelRus, Tenth UNR, Minskproekt), i.e., 3% out of ca. 120 design institutes operating in the field of civil construction engineering, which are introducing in their practice design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project. Two leading universities, i.e., Belarusian National Technical University and Belarusian State Technological University have adopted new courses on energy efficient building design and construction elaborated by the Project, and already more than 300 students in these universities are attending these courses. 3. The level is the same as for the baseline. The pilot buildings in Mahiliou and Minsk have been already commissioned but have not been inhabited yet. The pilot building in Hrodna is still under construction. 4. The level is the same as for the

1. The quality standards and a system of energy efficiency certification for the materials, equipment and component parts used in residential construction have been formally submitted for adoption. 2. Adoption of the integrated energy efficient building design approach together with buildings’ overall energy performance based design principles is made by increased number of design organisations with the target of at least 30% of all local design institutes by the end of the project. 3.The construction of demonstration buildings has been completed in line with the prepared design specifications and estimates, proposed energy efficiency standards and other quality standards and guidelines. The buildings have been placed in service. 4. State agency to take on the responsibility of monitoring energy saving and GHG emissions in the residential sector, and the procedure for the collection of necessary raw data, reporting and recording of these parameters has been proposed by the project, reviewed and adopted by the authorized government body; and the respective interagency agreement has been prepared.

1. The Technical Code "Energy Efficiency of Buildings", a regulatory enactment that contains, inter alia, the minimum energy performance requirements, corresponding provisions for energy certification and compliance checking systems and energy audit was finally approved by the Technical Committee on Standardization in the Field of Architecture Construction (TCS-14) and was incorporated into the State List of Technical Norms Standards Pending Adoption. The Ministry of Architecture Construction was assigned to develop a list of interrelated standards and national addenda and to elaborate a plan of measures for introduction of the Code by the end of 2017. 2. 13% of local design organizations are introducing in their practice the design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project. 3. All three pilot energy efficient buildings have been commissioned (in Mahiliou - Dec 2016, Minsk - Jan 2017, Hrodna - May 2017). The buildings have been inhabited by 25-30%. 4. Basic provisions and principles for a system that provides monitoring and analysis of data on energy savings and the methodology for calculation of GHG emissions in the housing sector were handed over to RUE Belarusian Research Centre "Ecology", mandated to perform activities related to the country's commitments under the UNFCC. Further communication will be held to develop and establish the system for monitoring energy saving and GHG emissions in the housing sector.

description.narrative: To reduce the energy consumption and related GHG emissions with the focus on new residential buildings
Amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the projected baseline

comment.narrative: Lifetime reduction of 220000 tons of CO2eq resulting from the energy saving in buildings for which the construction has started or which have adopted into their design new energy efficiency elements that reduce the energy consumption for heating and hot water in the residential buildings below the current thermal standards in force

179 thousand tons of CO2eq
The design and construction documentations for three pilot buildings in Hrodna Mahiliou and Minsk developed by the project have been submitted for the required state expertise New energy efficiency measures have been adopted into the design of these buildings ventilation heat recuperation heat pumps on sewage and geothermal sources solar heaters and solar PVpanels The project has been already proceeded to procurement of related equipment accessories and tools These provisions allow the projected annual specific energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply to be in the range of 5060 kWhm2 that is by ca 6070 kWhm2 per year lower than in the baseline case
If this design value is proven by actual construction the lifetime 30 years GHG emission reduction will be at least 179 thousand tons of CO2eq for the three buildings in total

comment.narrative: At least 10 around 80 buildings of all new residential multistorey buildings for which the design is started during the last year of the project are integrating new EE measures into their design with the target of reducing their combined annual energy demand for space heating and hot water below 60 kWhm2

There are no buildings constructed under the auspices of the project yet
The entire design and construction documentations have been completed by the project for three pilot buildings The documentations have been submitted to the State Construction Expertise for approval In these buildings according to their design the specific annual energy consumption for space heating and hot water supply will be less than 55 kWhm2
Since 2013 12 buildings apart from 3 project pilot buildings above are being designed using principles grounded and promoted by the project In these buildings the energy consumption for space heating already reduced to ca 30 kWhm2

Background studies preconstruction simulations and exploratory designs of measures technological methods installations and equipment for energy efficiency improvement of three pilot buildings and design of all three selected pilot buildings have been completed along with application of integrated building design principles and taking into account new technologies and approaches suggested and formulated by the project
The design and construction documentations of all three pilot buildings in Hrodna Mahiliou and Minsk have been developed and submitted to the state expertise for approval The construction documentation of the pilot building in Hrodna has been approved Such approval for construction documentations of other two buildings is expected in July 2015

In line with the commitments assumed in writing by the project partners they have covered the baseline cost of design and construction documentations for all three pilot buildings Recently the GrodnoGrazhdanProject informed the PIU that they will not be able to provide further sustainable financing of the pilot house in Grodno The PIU and UNDP CO have in cooperation with the Head of EE Department approached the Grodno authorities to settle this issue As a result another builder is ready to take over the initiative and commit itself to provide necessary financing of the construction in Grodno The project is currently waiting for a formal letter The two other partners reconfirmed in writing their financial commitments to support the baseline construction proven by corresponding Oblast authorities and submitted timeframes for design and construction of pilot buildings in Minsk and Mogilev
According to the design and construction documentations the energy performance of these buildings will be in line with the outcome target which stipulates for annual external energy demand for space heating and hot water supply to be equal or less than 60 kWhm2 and the cost of incremental energy efficiency measures will not exceed 15 of the total construction costs

Nonintegrated design of the buildings just complying with the current prescriptive thermal standards in force
Lack of capacity of the public authorities to effectively supervise and enforce the implementation of the planned new overall energy performance based norms and standards

Integrated energy efficient building design approach together with buildings overall energy performance based design principles adopted into the work of at least 30 of all local design institutes as well as into the curricula of all educational institutes in Belarus educating new architects and building construction and HVAC engineers
By the end of the project at least 50 experts from each key professional group see outputs 2226 and 200 university students have taken and successfully passed courses on energy efficient building design and constructionKey public authorities responsible for supervision and enforcement of the planned new norms and regulations trained

There are already 7 local design institutes ie NIPTIS MAPID Hrodnagrazhdanproekt Gomelgrazhdanproekt SaintGobain Construction Product BelRus Tenth UNR Minskproekt out of ca 120 design institutes operating in the field of civil construction engineering which are introducing in their practice design and construction of residential buildings with energy efficiency improvement components developed and advocated by the project
The project developed and disseminated about 40 special technical reports and guidelines on energy efficiency design principles The recommendations with cost efficiency analysis of different technical options applicable to the development of energy efficient residential buildings were prepared and discussed with stakeholders The recommendations are intended to be tested during the development of pilot buildings and will be included in national technical regulations and standards
More than 70 specialists
The analysis of target groups along with assessment of needs in their capacity building has been conducted and the capacity building action plan for 20142016 has been compiled discussed with Energy Efficiency Department and other stakeholders and approved Training textbooks have been drafted and disseminated
More than 70 specialists has developed their skills and increased knowledge for leading and managing effective energy audit in residential houses during three twoday training courses organized in Sep Oct and December 2014 One training course was conducted during actual energy audit measurements onsite
More than 70 specialists has taken and passed sixday training courses held in Hrodna and Minsk on energy efficient building design and construction new energy efficiency improvement policy norms and standards The trainings were attended by 29 companies designers engineers builders construction inspectors utilities representatives etc
The project provided support and organized logistics for 9 study visits and 10 international events abroad where about 30 decisionmakers designers builders and other relevant specialists have become acquainted with design construction and operation practices as well as with legal framework standards and policies exercised in four leading European countries Germany Austria England and France in the field of energy efficient residential buildings
No syllabus related to energy efficient building design principles has been adopted into the curricula of target educational institutes in Belarus yet No student has passed the courses yet
The critical analysis of curricula of different relevant universities has been conducted and the proposals for its improvement and updating have been presented in a project report along with a list of suggested university courses Based on the report recommendations for relevant university curricular updates have been drafted presented and approved at two roundtables about 60 representatives of stakeholders have participated
Three new courses related to the best international and national practice in the field of design and construction of energy efficient residential buildings were suggested and presented by the project During roundtable discussions held in the Belarusian National Technical University conjointly with Scientific Council Meeting with presence of representatives from 14 faculties of 7 universities three national universities agreed to include these new courses in their syllabi The decision has been made to continue cooperation with the said faculties in order to further adjust the curricular materials prepared by the project to current syllabi

description.narrative: Strengthened legal and regulatory framework and mechanisms to enforce the legislation for improving the energy efficiency of the building sector with the focus on new residential buildings
Status of the national laws and other regulatory documents controlling the energy consumption of the newly constructed buildings

comment.narrative: Prescriptive thermal standards adopted in 2010 defining minimum mandatory Uvalues for the building envelope corresponding to the average annual heat demand of 60 kWhm2 for space heating of typical multiapartment buildings and 120130 kWh m2 together with sanitary hot water preparation

Revised minimum energy performance standards adopted for new construction and reaching a status of a law by the end of the project with a target of reducing the energy consumption of new residential buildings for space heating and hot water together below 60 kWhm2
An energy performance certification and labelling scheme for both new and existing buildings adopted and under implementation by the end of the project

No minimum energy performance standards reaching a status of a law have been adopted yet
The project elaborated a draft of the Technical Code On Energy Efficiency of Buildings which is based on EU Directive 201031EU concerning integral energy performance of residential buildings along with the list of related national technical regulatory acts These documents were incorporated into the Plan of State Standardization for 2015 and into the State Development Program of Technical Regulation Standardization and Conformity Assessment in the Field of Energy Saving for 20112015 Both programmes were duly adopted and the project submitted the drafts of elaborated documents to the Technical Committee for Standardization in the Field of Energy Efficiency TCS14 for consideration and approval The said TCS14 was created by the Ministry of Architecture and Construction due to initiatives and support provided by the project Three project consultants were coopted to be members of TCS14 and one of them has become a chair of TCS14
As an integral part of national applications to the said Technical Code the project drafted some new standards Some of these standards have been already submitted and adopted in particular Method of calculation of specific heat consumption for heating and ventilation in residential buildings Energy performance of buildings Assessment of overall energy consumption and energy performance of buildings Energy efficiency of buildings Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification buildings amendments to Thermal protection of buildings Energy performance characteristics Rules of definition
The project has prepared a draft of the methodological guidelines based on the IPMVprotocol and in line with the best international practice and with due account of national provisions for energy audit and energy performance monitoring and calculation applicable to residential buildings The draft has been verified during energy auditing of 30 multistorey residential buildings in 20132015 and adjusted accordingly It will be used for carrying out of energy audits of 25 other multistorey residential buildings in 20152016 and further enter a corresponding adoption procedure Four twoday training workshops were organized and held in 20132014 for more than 70 professional energy auditors
No energy performance certification and labeling scheme for residential buildings have been adopted yet
In technical standard Energy efficiency of buildings Methods for determination of energy efficiency and energy certification of buildings the project and its partners first introduced a scheme similar to the energy performance certification system This scheme is suggested in a building energy efficiency passport format which is to be issued as an integral part of design and construction documentations and contains all major requisites for energy performance certification Next in the second part of 2015 the project should elaborate practical procedures for the energy certification system and a system of monitoring and compliance checking applicable to residential buildings
To do this the project organized and held two roundtables for relevant stakeholders where main principles and framework of the certification system were discussed and provided further necessary consulting services to the StroyTechNorm RUE and to members of the TCS14 As of Nov 26 2014 the suggestions mentioned above were considered and approved by the said Technical Committee for further adoption procedure The project will continue its efforts in consulting the authorities using in particular such instrument as TCS14 until the said documents are duly adopted

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

Component 1:
1. % of pilot schools acknowledge improved awareness of pupils and their parents on the benefits of rational use of energy and energy efficient measures. 2. % of project territories in the region covered by the information campaign within the project.
Component 2: 1. No. of successfully implemented pilot initiatives demonstrating basic energy-saving measures and innovative energy-saving measures in the area of energy efficiency in schools. 2. No. of completed energy audits.
Component 3: 1. No. of representatives of local stakeholders trained in Area-Based Development participatory practices. 2. No. of public hearings conducted in every target region/territory.

comment.narrative:
Component 1: 1. There’s little awareness of and adherence to energy-saving techniques among general population in Belarus.
Component 2: 1. The use of energy resources in old public buildings, especially schools, is often characterized by energy waste and increased GHGs emission.
Component 3: 1. Local population is not actively involved into sustainable local development planning.

Targets as per Component 1:
- The quarterly information newsletter is issued on a regular basis. - The project thematic web-site is up-to-date and operational. - Elective EE curriculum is available in pilot schools. - Information stands are updated regularly at pilot project sites. - The information campaign is conducted throughout the year.
Targets as per Component 2:
- On-going support to the pilot initiative implementation and mobilization of resources is provided. - Project impact monitoring and energy monitoring is conducted on a regular basis. - At least three in-country study tours are conducted for experience sharing. - Opening ceremonies of the pilot sites are conducted. - At least 6 seminars are conducted for the result dissemination. - At least 20 participants from Belarus will present the project results at about 5 international trade fairs or conferences.
Targets as per Component 3:
- Public Advisory Boards are operational in all target districts. - Town Hall Meetings are conducted in target districts on a regular basis/ - Participatory monitoring and evaluation system is operational in all the target districts. - Each target district has EE local development strategies. - Final report on the lessons learnt is prepared and presented to the relevant partners and stakeholders presenting a summary of project results.

Resullts as per Component 1:
- 5 quarterly issues of information newsletter are published and disseminated. - English version of The Project's website was created and launched. The Project's website is regularly updated in Russian and English. - In Educational Establishment "Vitebsk State Vocational College of Mechanical Engineering named after M.F.Shmyrev" energy efficiency elective classes were introduced. State Educational Establishment "Secondary School No.4 of Dzerzhinsk town" didn't introduced energy efficiency elective classes. Energy efficiency issues are included in the educational process with childrens. Active work in fiels of energy efficiency is cinducts in this direction with both parents, staff of sthe educational establishment and with local communities. Questions of energy efficiency are included in the the Annual Working Plan for 2016/2017 academic year. - Four information stands demonstrated the energy efficiency measures applied in pilot schools and the benefits gained from the project are created, installed and regularly updated in targeted education establishments of Vitebsk, Grodno and Minsk regions. - The information campaign is running.
Results as per Component 2:
- On-going support to the pilot initiative implementation and mobilization of resources was provided. Educational Department of the Vitebsk Regional Executive Committee allocated financial resources for EE "Vitebsk State Vocational Mechanical Engineering College named after M.F.Shmyrev" in sum of 342,810 USD and Department of Energy Efficiency allocated 75,000 USD. Educational Department of the Oshmiany District Executive Committee allocated 216,834 USD for SEE "Kindergarten No.6 of Oshmiany town" and administration of the Leninski district of Grodno city aloocated 206,164 USD for SEE "Kindergarten No.45 of Grodno city". Educational Department of the Dzerzhinsk District Executice Committee allocated 355,809 USD for SEE "Secondary School No.4 of Dzerzhinsk town" and Department

Targets as per Component 1:
- The quarterly information newsletter is issued on a regular basis. - The project thematic web-site is up-to-date and operational. - Information stands are updated regularly at pilot project sites. - The information campaign is conducted throughout the year.
Targets as per Component 2: - Capacity building of local authorities and other stakeholders in implementing EE pilot projects - Dissemination of project results.
Targets as per Component 3: - Manuals for local governments and other stakeholders on EE issues, citizens' participation and planning at local level. - Assistance in developing local EE strategies. - Presentation of the final report.

Results as per Component 1: - 1 quarterly issue of information newsletter is published and disseminated. - The site (English and Russian versions) has been regularly updated. During 2017 project website was visited by 834 guests. Total number of visits - 1299. Pages looked through - 3281. - Information about the Project's activities is regularly posted and updated on UNDP’s official webpages. - Interviews and printed thematic materials about the experience of the preparation and implementation of project activities were published. Four videos featuring different uses of RES, energy efficient appliances, modern ventilation systems, simple actions for the rational uses of energy at home and at school were created.
Results as per Component 2: - 11 participants took part in the workshop and increased their knowledge and awareness in exploitation, maintaining and services of the energy efficient equipment installed at the pilot sites. - Two seminars with participation of 154 representatives of the local authorities, education institutions were organized and two local study tour to Viciebsk and Hrodna pilot sites for dissemination of the project results and findings were organized. 4 Belarusian experts took part in two International forums and conferences amd presented the project results.
Results as per Component 3: - Manuals for local executive and administrative authorities and other stakeholders on energy efficiency prepared. - Recommendations on local energy efficiency strategies developed. - 60 participants took part in the final conference where final results and findings were presented.

activity-description.narrative: To address the most critical problems of peatland conservation and management and to demonstrate innovative approaches to ecosystem-based climate mitigation and adaptation at one of the largest natural fen mires in Europe, Sporovo peatland, in Bereza district in Belarus.

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

Output 1 Indicators: 1) Peatland territory cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees within the project. 2) Amount of biomass harvested from peatlands within the project.
Output 2 Indicators: Ecological integrity of the ecosystem (density of indicator species populations, such as Aquatic Warbler, Curlew, Great Snipe), carbon dividends; volumes of biomass harvested, areas of open peatlands freed of shrubs and undergrowth; and groundwater table dynamics.

comment.narrative: Output 1 Baseline: 1) 200 ha at Sporovo fen mire under grassy biomass cleared (implemented as part of an ICI project). 2) 0 tons of biomass harvested within the project. Output 2 Baseline: No system for monitoring of the efficiency of biomass harvesting is in place
1. 3,500 ha of fen mires at Sporovo and Zvanets cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees. 2. 2,500 tons harvested. 3. A robust monitoring system based on the objectively variable indicators.

1. 2,301 ha of fen mires at Sporovo and Zvanets cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees. 2. 3,485 tons tons harvested. 3. Water regime monitoring through construction and functioning of water-regulating devices on Zvaniec territory ensured elevation and stabilisation of GWT in 2016 at the favorable for peatland ecosystem levels. Scientific analysis made on the influence of managed fires on peatland ecosystems and prepared appropriate recommendations for the Ministry of Forestry and Ministry of Emergency. Analysis of factors made which determinate peatland overgroving with shrubs and reeds. Data collected on the ecosystems condition after cutting trees, bushes and reed. Received necessary data for preparation of vegetation large-scale maps of the project territories. Calculation of Aquatic Warbler species at the monitoring spots at reserves Zvaniec and Sporauski conducted. Density of Aquatic Warbler species at the sites optimal for nesting exceeds 2015 year quantities in 1.5-2 times. This is indicative of reduced threats and improved quality of habitat for globally threatened species.

1. 3,500 ha of fen mires at Sporovo and Zvaniec cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees. 2. 2,500 tons of biomass harvested from peatlands 3. A robust monitoring system based on the objectively variable indicators is in place

1. 3,893 ha of fen mires at Sporovo and Zvaniec cleared of shrubs, reeds, and trees. 2. 4,062 tons of biomass harvested from peatlands 3. Monitoring programme for "Zvaniec” and “Sporaŭski” reserves was designed and adjusted based on the practical outputs; monitoring survey of the wetland ecosystems before, during and after the harvesting was completed (indicator species, vegetation proportions, water level monitoring). Monitoring surveys of the vegetation in Reserves were conducted. Large-scale vegetation maps (1:100 000) and maps of succession processes in the ecosystems of the project territories were developed. Monitoring of the globally threatened bird species (Aquatic Warbler, Great Snipe, and Eurasian Curlew) in the mires of the reserves was carried out at 11 sites. Monitoring of the status of populations of indicator insect groups in the mires of Zvaniec and Sporava was carried out. Operating rules for water regulating facilities in the territory of the Zvaniec Reserve were designed. System for precise identification of the carbon dividends is in place.

Defence - policy, planning and administration

Outcome 1: - The document of a new SBC Human Resources Development and Training Strategy for 5 years is in place (drafted, signed and endorsed). - The document of training curricular for SBC educational institutions (e.g. Smorgon Border Training Centre of the Institute of Border Service) is in place and updated in accordance with the HR Development and Training Strategy). - Number of SBC personnel and cadets trained according to a new SBC Human Resources Development and Training Strategy. - Training complex and a dormitory of the Smorgon Border Training Centre reconstructed and modernized.
Outcome 2: - The document of Strategy and Action Plan for capacity building of SBC Psychological Support Service including training modules is in place. - Number of new services of the SBC PSS provided to target groups. - Number of clients assisted by PSS. - Mobile Unit of Psychological and Medical Assistance is in place and function.
Outcome 3: - Document of Standard Operational Procedures on Prevention and Response to SGBV is in place, signed and approved by the authorized body of the State Border Committee. - Multidisciplinary team of specialists is in place and function. - Number of new services provided to migrants in detention centres and other categories of irregular migrants by the Multidisciplinary team of specialists. - Number of migrants in detention centres and other categories of irregular migrants served by the Multidisciplinary team of specialists. - Number of SBC and NGOs personnel trained to more effectively address SGBV and THB cases. - Number of victims of human trafficking received adequate protection and reintegration services

comment.narrative:
Outcome 1: - Current Human Resources Development strategy of SBC is not in line with EU IBM good practices and norms. - Current training curriculum for SBC personnel is outdated and does not comply with SBC reform from military organization into a law enforcement agency. - Infrastructure and technical state of the Smorgon Border Training Centre does not provide appropriate conditions for education process and accommodation of trainees.
Outcome 2: - Psychological Support Service is lacking i) a development strategy, ii) qualified instructors, and iii) experienced psychologists. - PSS technical capacity is not sufficient to expand geographical outreach of services and rich out new target groups.
Outcome 3: - Border officers are lacking specific skills and infrastructure facilities to be able to deal with the vulnerable categories of migrants and to refer them for adequate support and assistance in line with international standards. - Irregular migrants, and primarily asylum seekers are vulnerable to sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) and require protection and assistance services. - Networking with civil society organizations and their role in addressing SGBV issues is underused.

Outcome 1:
1.1. The document of a new SBC Human Resources Development and Training Strategy for 5 years is in place (drafted, signed and endorsed). 1.2. Improvement of the infrastructure and technical capacity of the Smarhon Border Training Centre of the Institute through the construction of a modern building with modern training facilities included construction of a one-floor barrack located at the territory of the Smarhon Border Training Centre of the Institute into a lecture room and a conference-hall for trainings, administrative and living blocks.
Outcome 2: 2.1.Mobile Unit of Psychological and Medical Assistance is in place and functions
Outcome 3: 3.1. Increase the number of victims of human trafficking received adequate protection and reintegration services 3.2. Increase the number of SBC and NGOs personnel trained to more effectively address SGBV and THB cases

Outcome 1:
1.1. Design of SBC Human Resources Development and Training Strategy along with detailed action plan of the future process of building up a recruitment and professional training system for border guards taking into consideration good practices from EUMS as well as EU agencies was launched and duly adopted by the SBC. The strategy defined vision, objectives and priorities of SBC for personnel recruitment, training/retraining for 5-year period; 1.2. The construction of the 1-floor barrack with the lecturer room for 120 persons, conference-hall for 50 persons, utility rooms and a section for service personnel of the Border Institute of the Republic of Belarus in Smarhon, Hrodna region, was completed and launched into operation in October 2016.
Outcome 2: 2.1. Vehicle-based Mobile Unit of Psychological and Medical Assistance is equipped and fully operational including special equipment for PSS units supported growing capacity of PSS staff as well as created necessary preconditions for PSS reaching new target groups with new services.
Outcome 3: 3.1. 14 VoTs (1 male, 5 females and 8 minors) received access to rehabilitation assistance provided by IOM at the Rehabilitation Centre
3.2. - 14 State Border Committee psychologists and 10 NGO social workers were trained by experts from NGO ASPACIA (Madrid, Spain) at the 5th educational seminar “Basic values and work experience with victims and aggressors of sexual and gender-based violence among migrants”; - 12 SBC psychologists and 9 NGO social workers increased their knowledge on prophylaxis of professional burning out of specialists working with SGBV victims and diagnosing trauma and ways of addressing it at the 6th educational seminar held on 23-24 June in Minsk
Outcome 4: To ensure proper project closure and documentation of achieved results and lessons learned
Outcome 4: Proper project closure and documentation of achieved results and lessons learned is completed

Favorable legal environment for establishing tax advisory services created, institutionalized tax advisory services promoted.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Minsk, Belarus

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

1) Draft legislation governing the work of tax advisors, and a package of tax advisor training materials. 2) Tax advisor training facility is operational; number of trained and certified tax advisors. 3) New tax advisory model tested in the pilot enterprises from various sectors. 4) Increased awareness of tax advisory services among business, government authorities and other stakeholders.

comment.narrative: 1) No institutional or legal framework in place, no enabling mechanism for tax advisory services exists. 2) There is no training or certification of consultants. 3) No experience of outsourcing tax advisory services to third party providers. 4) Little awareness among the public and private sectors about tax advisory services, little public-private interaction taking place.

1. The legislation on tax advising approved by the President of Republic of Belarus 2. At least 28 of tax advisors are certified 3. Booklet on becoming a tax adviser prepared, posted on web-site of Ministry of Taxes and Duties

1. The legislation on tax advising is expected to be approved by the President of Republic of Belarus in December 2016. 2. Booklet on becoming a tax adviser prepared and will be posted after approving the edict on tax advisory. Comments: The risks to timely completion of the project were discussed at a meeting of the Project Steering Board on 11 May 2016. Given the significant number of activities that are conditional on the enactment of the Edict, and also that they are expected to take at least eight months to complete, the following decisions were made: 1. Request UNDP to grant an extension of the project by at least six months.

1. Tax outsourcing tested in five enterprises from different sectors 2. A cost benefit analysis of tax outsourcing performed and the results of piloting presented to the business 3. Informational workshops conducted in Minsk and three regions 4. Project results presented at the final project conference

1. Tax outsourcing has been tested by five companies, including a private sector retailer in Brest, a retailer with a share of government ownership (an open joint-stock company based in Minsk), and a private manufacturing enterprise in Minsk. Free tax advice sessions were provided to 35 clients of the business incubator "Youth Social Service". Project consultants have identified and described the key business processes of the tax outsourcing model, the list of primary accounting documents necessary for the correct calculation of the taxes, the submission and transmission procedures that would prevent potential disputes. The managers and business owners have been surveyed to identify potential barriers and economic benefits to the parties. 2.The pilot has revealed a range of benefits and advantages of tax outsourcing: • The services are provided by a team of skilled professionals, which reduces the risks of errors in tax calculation; • Insurance against tax-related risks. Unlike a physical person or a company division, a specialized provider of tax services is in the position to conclude a civil liability agreement and to secure guarantees of its ability to provide monetary compensation for eventual damage or incurred by the client. • Contacts with the tax authorities are the personalist of the tax adviser, who possesses good technical and substantive knowledge and can speak the same language with the tax officers; • Reduction in personnel costs, by eliminating expenses such as: monthly salaries, vacation pay, and fringe benefits to regular accounting staff; acquisition of professional journals, purchase and installation of reference databases, workplace equipment, etc. • sick and maternity leave, vacation pay. A specialized outsourcing company will have a flexible staff of regular employees, and typically guarantees delivery of services regardless of the personal situations of its employees. • Reduction in exposure to fraud. comment.narrative: 1. Insufficient knowledge and awareness of the benefits of green production and consumption among the public, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and business community. 2. The potential for greening the economy of the Republic of Belarus is underexploited. Economic empowerment of territories based on green growth principles is required in the areas of waste management, water management, biodiversity conservation, ecotourism, and creation of eco-info centres. 3. There are no effective partnerships and joint action mechanisms for NGOs, local administrations and businesses to implement economically feasible projects based on green growth ideas. NGOs tend to be passive in the implementation of projects aimed at generating added value. NGOs primarily focus on implementation of initiatives related to public information and addressing environmental problems without due regard to economic development aspects as a basis for ensuring sustainability of the results in the future

1. Expanding public knowledge of the principles and ideas of green economy. 2. Developing Green Economy in the regions through implementation of pilot initiatives. 3. Creating effective partnership and joint action mechanisms for NGOs, local administrations and businesses to implement economically feasible projects based on green growth ideas in such areas as waste management, ecotourism, conservation of biodiversity (aimed at bird or fish conservation, activities at wetlands etc.), renewable energy promotion, etc.

1. 105 publications on project, 1150 stakeholders participated in 10 PR actions, 9000 copies of publications on different directions of green economy, 54770 people visited project web-site and web-pages, 12742 unique visitors of the "green" map data base, 1646 users of electric bus, 40 people were trained in the information ecological center of "Pribuzhskoye Polesie" Nature Reserve, 10300 tourists visited "Svityazyansky" Nature Reserve, the Forum of introduction of ecological decisions into the economy with 175 participants. 2. EUR 2,286,840 were contributed by the project beneficiaries, 22 new jobs were established, business-plans for the implementation of all 4 pilot initiatives were developed and duly approved, financial sustainability of new productions established in the result of implementation of 3 pilot projects is ensured, environmental benefits of new productions established in the result of implementation of4 pilot projects are demonstrated. 3. 16 green initiatives were implemented by 150 NGOs, US$ 92 900 as co-financing were contributed by the NGOs.

1. Expanding public knowledge of the principles and ideas of green economy. 2. Developing Green Economy in the regions through implementation of pilot initiatives. 3. Creating effective partnership and joint action mechanisms for NGOs, local administrations and businesses to implement economically feasible projects based on green growth ideas in such areas as waste management, ecotourism, conservation of biodiversity (aimed at bird or fish conservation, activities at wetlands etc.), renewable energy promotion, etc.

Tower for observation over the birds was constructed on the territory of the "Pribuzhskoye Polesie" Nature Reserve. Two roundtables on promotion of green economy were held. Outcome 4: 4.1. To conduct the analysis of the Action Plan on Sustainable Energy Development for Novogrudok to identify activities with the highest indicators of energy efficiency and reduction of CO2 emissions. To make an adjustment of the SEAP for Novogrudok. 4.2. To define barriers for the transition to green urban development in Belarus; identify basic needs and opportunities of various stakeholders in green urban development in Belarus.

Outcome 1: 1.1. An overview of the governmental regulatory system in urban development policy as well as the international experience in the area is made. 1.2. An overview of the existing policy, standards and rules in the filed of development of sustainable urban transport (including the experience of implementation of the incentive mechanisms for the renewal of the transport park; development of cycling infrastructure in cities) is prepared. 1.3. An overview of the existing national standards and norms of street lighting and lighting in residential buildings considering the installation of LED lighting ia made.
Outcome 2: 2.1. An analysis of the initiatives to develop sustainable transport implemented in Novopolotsk and Polotsk, was conducted. Goals and objectives of the ISUMP were defined. 2.2. The report on best international practices in development of integrated sustainable transport system that can be used in sustainable transport in Belarus, in Polotsk and Novopolotsk pilot sites, was developed.
Outcome 3: 3.1. Preliminary feasibility studies on implementation of a pilot project for the installation of LED street lighting in Novogrudok with systems for monitoring and control and re-equipment and modernization of the city laundry were prepared. The contract for development of a feasibility study of a pilot project for the installation of LED street lighting in Novogrudok with monitoring and control systems was signed. The contractor performed an energy survey of the city's light points, identified the main streets for the replacement of lighting equipment, selected the best options for the equipment and calculated the efficiency of its use.
Outcome 4: 4.1. Analysis of the Action Plan on Sustainable Energy Development in Novogrudok was conducted to identify activities with the highest energy efficiency and CO2 emission reduction. Updated version of SEAP was developed and submitted to the key stakeholders for discussion.

description.narrative: 1. % of planned oversight activities completed with documented participation by all CCM constituencies. 2. % of CCM members trained on the role of the CCM. 3. % of non-government CCM members with documented selection by their own constituency according to clear criteria.

comment.narrative: No CCM oversight system and CCM oversight activities. Insufficient involvement of the NGO representatives into oversight activities and their interconnection with their constituencies. Limited capacity in correspondence to the GFATM requirements.

1. Introduction of CCM oversight system and strengthening CCM oversight activities on analysis and monitoring with 100% events held. 2. Involvement of the NGO representatives into oversight activities and their interconnection with their constituencies under the principles of 100% transparency and well documented processes. 3. Strengthening CCM capacity in correspondence to the GFATM requirements with 100% of CCM members trained on the role of the CCM within the preceding 24 months.

1. For the first time from 2004, 2016 Work plan of Oversight Board was developed and agreed on CCM Meeting on April 4, 2016. In compliance with the plan, 5 official trips to 7 cities where Global Fund Grants` services are provided have been made. O2 meetings of CCM members as NGO representatives with their constituencies were held in 2016 in Viciebsk, Homiel and Hrnly 54,5% events held vs scheduled due to unavailability of Oversight Board members representing state sector to take part in events as per schedule. 2. Elections of CCM members from NGOs were held on December 10 in Minsk under the principles of 100% transparency and well documented processes. 78 representatives from NGOs from 12 cities took part in elections. 3. In terms of strengthening CCM capacity in correspondence to the GFATM requirements 57% of CCM members and 100% of Oversight board members trained on the role of the CCM in March 2016. A second training to be held in Q1 of 2017.

1. Further strengthening of CCM oversight activities on analysis and monitoring. 2. Broader involvement of the NGO representatives into oversight activities and their interconnection with their constituencies. 3. Strengthening CCM capacity in its correspondence to the GFATM requirements and in fulfillment of its main functions.

1. ССM Oversight Committee Plan for 2017 was developed and approved by CCM. The following events were organized and realized in accordance with the Oversight Committee Plan: four regular meetings of the Oversight Committee, six Oversight Committee visits to grant implementation units: 1) Rechitsa-Homiel; 2) Hrodna-Lida; 3) Viciebds-Polack; 4) Homiel-Rechitsa-Svetlahorsk; 5) Mahileu-Babruisk; 6) Salihorsk-Slutsk. Consultant was hired to review and update CCM documents, including Practical Guidance on Monitoring and Analysis and Observation and Analysis Plan. Work plan on sustainability provision for national response to HIV and tuberculosis was worked out. 2 working meetings on evaluation of the Plan on Realization of Sustainable Development of the Prevention and Treatment System for HIV and tuberculosis were held. 2. Four meetings of NGO members with their constituencies and civil society stakeholders were organized in different regions: 1) In Mahileu; 2) In Homiel; 3) In Brest; 4) In Viciebsk. Focus groups have been held among population at high risk of HIV and TB infection to assess the need for HIV/AIDS and TB related services for constituencies. Two trainings for NGO members were organized: 1) On monitoring of rights observation and mechanism of legal regulation of rights of the people with HIV. 2) On effective negotiations. 3. Six CCM meetings were prepared and organized. Four working meetings of CCM working group members were organized. CCM website page was translated into English. Promotional materials with CCM logo were designed and produced.

1. Further strengthening of CCM oversight activities on analysis and monitoring. 2. Broader involvement of the NGO representatives into oversight activities and their interconnection with their constituencies. 3. Strengthening CCM capacity in its correspondence to the GFATM requirements and in fulfillment of its main functions.

1. ССM Oversight Committee Plan for 2018 was developed and approved by CCM. The work of Consultant on update and review of CCM documents, including Practical Guidance on Monitoring and Analysis and Observation and Analysis Plan was completed. 2. One working meetings of CCM working group members was organized. A training on CCM Orientation with the participation of international trainer from the Global Fund was organized.

description.narrative: Indicator(s): 1. The ITC training programmes updated to reflect the advanced anti-trafficking methods and best practices in response to the existing needs. 2. Human rights and gender equality topics integrated in the programme contents. 3. Five training courses for 125 law-enforcement professionals conducted in the field of combating trafficking in hu-man beings and related offences. Indicators: 1. An enhanced system is in place to sup-port coordination and information ex-change on human trafficking and related offences among the law enforcement agencies and other competent authorities of Belarus and the neighbouring states. 2. Strengthened human rights focus of in-ternational cooperation against human trafficking among the members of the Group of Friends and international organi-sations.

comment.narrative:
Baseline: The contents of the existing training programmes on combating human trafficking and related of-fences need to be upgraded and updated with regard to the latest trends in the criminal context dynamics. Advanced international anti-trafficking methods, including those for Internet, have to be researched and introduced. The focus to strengthen human rights and gender equality needs to be enhanced. Baseline: There is a need to improve the effectiveness of measures to prevent the victimization of women and children, as well as to elaborate a coordinat-ed approach to addressing the root causes of trafficking.
There is a need to improve coordination of the relevant agencies of the Group of Friends to hu-man trafficking to develop more uniform ap-proaches to protecting the human rights of vic-tims of human trafficking.

1. 130 professionals from Belarus, the CIS and neighboring countries have completed training courses in the field of combating trafficking in human beings and related offenses. 2. Human rights and gender perspective topics are integrated into the training curriculum. 3. Advanced methods of detection, recording and investigation of crimes related to human trafficking have been incorporated in the professional practices of the law enforcement agencies from Belarus, CIS and neighboring countries represented at the training courses. 4. 30 law-enforcement professionals and other competent authorities from Belarus, International organizations and NGOs have taken part in the workshop. 5. Exchange of information on anti-trafficking and coordination among the law enforcement agencies and other competent authorities in Belarus, International organizations and NGOs have been optimized.

1. 3 workshops were conducted with the total number of participants equaling to 125. 2. Exchange of information on anti-trafficking and coordination among the law enforcement agencies and other competent authorities in Belarus have been optimized with participation of representatives from international organizations, NGOs, over 50 national ministries and embassies representatives. 3. Advanced methods of detection, recording and investigation of crimes related to human trafficking have been incorporated in the professional practices of the law enforcement agencies from Belarus, CIS and neighbouring countries represented at the training courses.

1. 2 Training courses on multi-agency child safeguarding and tackling child sexual exploitation held. 2. 30 representatives of stakeholder ministries and law enforcement entities (Ministry of Internal Affairs, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Labour, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Social Protection, State Boarder Committee) have completed training courses in the field of multi-agency child safeguarding and tackling child sexual exploitation.

1. 2 Training courses on multi-agency child safeguarding and tackling child sexual exploitation held as scheduled. 2. 30 representatives of stakeholder ministries and law enforcement entities (Ministry of Internal Affairs, Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Labor, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Social Protection, State Boarder Committee) have completed training courses in the field of multi-agency child safeguarding and tackling child sexual exploitation.

activity-description.narrative: Republic of Belarus

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

1. Representatives of local governments (committees on economy) and the staff of the small and medium-sized towns from the selected oblasts of Belarus trained to work in the SRER framework. 2. A complete development and implementation cycle of the SME support and development plans tested at town-forming SOEs. 3. Pilot Industrial Service Platforms (ISP) - incubators - set up using the premises of the restructured SOEs to accommodate small businesses employing the released personnel. 4. Total value (USD) of dedicated loans issued to SMEs established with the support of the project 5. Small and medium-sized enterprises established due to the measures to support entrepreneurship and industrial cooperation in pilot towns. 6. National Subcontracting Centre (NSC) established. 7. Cooperation agreements signed, including businesses from the Russian Federation and the Republic of Kazakhstan. 8. The professional capacity in the field of industrial cooperation and investment attraction improved: experts trained to analyse value chains, to apply international best practices in the social and economic development of small towns and to enhance competitiveness of the selected regions.

comment.narrative: No concept of socially responsible approach to SME development in small and medium-sized towns of Belarus. No business incubators / training centers for small and medium businesses (SME) at the selected town-forming enterprises. Limited conditions for the development of small business and production cooperation in small and medium-sized towns.

1. 300 people taking part in the information and education project activities, which will significantly increase the level of awareness about the fundamentals of entrepreneurship, SRER and production cooperation methods in the government, public and business sectors. 2. 50 representatives of local governments (committees on economy) and the staff of the small and medium-sized towns from the selected oblasts of Belarus trained to work in the SRER framework. 3. 30 national experts trained to teach small business entrepreneurship to the those released from the SOEs
Results not achieved as the project is under registration.

1. At least 10 people from national and oblast level have learned about the implementation of programs for supporting small and medium businesses in the Russian Federation 2. Presentations and meetings covering the issues of the socially responsible approach have been held with at least 300 participants 3. Popular handbook on business basics has been drafted and published, with regard to the business conditions in small and medium-sized towns 4. 5 SME support and development plans for the incubators in the pilot towns have been drafted (considering the business conditions in small and medium-sized towns) 5. 5 pilot towns with large state enterprises have been chosen for participation in the project. The rationale is set out in the analytical note. 6. 30 national experts have been prepared in Vitebsk and Mogilev oblasts to conduct trainings on business basics. 7. Necessary repairs and equipment have been provided for at least 3 incubators in the pilot towns for hosting small enterprises and individual entrepreneurs. 8. The NSC development concept has been created. Additional premises for the offices of NSC and videoconference room have been equipped, necessary computer equipment and software has been purchased. 9. At least 2 business matchmaking sessions (BMS) for SMEs and large enterprises have been organized, with participation of Russian businesses.

1. 24 specialists from the national and oblast level have learned the practice of implementing federal and regional employment and self-employment programs, federal target program for economic development and life quality improvement in small towns of the Russian Federation during study tours to St. Petersburg (15-19 May 2017, 11 participants) and Kazan (10-13 December 2017, 13 participants). 2. Presentations and meetings covering the issues of the socially responsible approach have been held with at least 620 participants in Minsk, Vitebsk, Orsha (Vitebsk oblast) and Bobruisk (Mogilev oblast). 3. Popular handbook on business has been published, 500 psc. Necessary repairs and equipment have been purchased for the incubators in the pilot towns Glubokoe, Krichev and Chausy to prepare them for hosting small enterprises and individual entrepreneurs. 8. • An assessment review of the current system of selection, training and performance evaluation of civil servants in Belarus was conducted by experts of the Academy of Public Administration. The Academy of Public Administration was supported in their work by two international consultants, Professor Jurgita Siugzdiniene, expert in public management, and Mr. Jaba Devdariani, expert in public administration and civil service reform. • Series of seminars organized in cooperation with the Academy of Public Administration to study international practices and experiences in different aspects of processes of selection, training, and evaluation of civil servants: a) Two-day training seminar “Public Service in the Republic of Belarus - Topical Issues of Evaluation of the Impact of the Civil Service System Functioning: Best World Practices and Perspectives of their Use in the Republic of Belarus,” held on 3-4 November 2016. b) One-day training seminar “Public Service in the Republic of Belarus - Topical Issues of Selection: Best World Practices and Perspectives of their Use in the Republic of Belarus,” held on 18 November 2016. c) Conference “Improvement of Internet resources of public administration in accordance with international standards and current practices,” held on 25 November 2016 d) One-day training seminar “Improvement of the existing system of performance evaluation of civil servants,” held on 2 December 2016 with the purpose of studying different methodologies and international experiences of performance evaluation of civil servants, as well as reviewing their corresponding methodologies. e) One-day training seminar “Development of HR policies in public administration,” held on 9 December 2016 aiming at studying different approaches and experiences to civil service and public administration HR-policy management and development. f) Conference “Building civil servants’ capacities to apply the principles of inclusive governance at the national and local level,

• According to the request of the National Project Coordinator, a seminar on the issues of e-government was held. • A room at the Academy of Public Administration has been equipped to provide trainings for civil servants. • Sociological studies on the issues of satisfaction of the quality of the rendered public services by population have been performed by the international agency of social and marketing research (MASMI). • Agreement with the Executing agency NCLLR has been signed. • According to the request of the National Project Coordinator and in partnership with the National Centre of Electronic Services a round table on the topic “Practice of e-Government in the Republic of Belarus. Interdepartmental Interaction” was held. • Meetings were organized in the regions of the republic with the purpose of analyzing the locations of future pilot sites for the MFC. The meetings were attended by the representatives of NCLLR, who were responsible for drafting the concept of MFC development within the project. Premises in Hrodna, Mahiliou and Lida were inspected. • Agreement between UNDP and NCLLR has been signed. Main results: - Analytical report on foreign experience of MFC functioning and possibilities of its application in the Republic of Belarus. - The concept of the activity of the Multifunctional Centers in the Republic of Belarus was developed and discussed at the national and local levels, including analysis regarding the possibilities of existing information intermediaries (Belpochta and Beltelecom) in the provision of public services. - Draft Decree of the President of the Republic of Belarus on the activities of multi-functional centers in the Republic of Belarus has been developed. - Regulation on the Procedure for Holding the Contest of Local Initiatives within the framework of the Project designed. comment.narrative:
The Agenda for Sustainable Development for the period until 2030 (Agenda 2030) was adopted at the UN Summit in 2015. Agenda 2030 sets out the principle "leave no one behind" and is supported by an interlinked set of 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Each country is encouraged to implement the Agenda 2030 and the SDGs to track progress and to inform the UN on the progress of their implementation. The SDGs will be implemented and monitored against national indicators included in the national plans and development strategies. Thus, “localization” is one of the key elements in the implementation of the SDGs. The Parliament plays an important role in supporting all these efforts. The SDGs replaced the Millennium Development Goals that were successfully achieved by the Republic of Belarus before the deadline. Belarus attaches great importance to the successful implementation of the Agenda 2030 and the SDGs. "Nationalization" of the SDGs has been initiated by the Republic of Belarus with the establishment of the post of National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals and the establishment under his/her leadership the Council for Sustainable Development. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs performs the function of the Secretariat of the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals. Belarus has become one of 44 countries that will present national reviews on SDGs implementation at the political forum of the UN high-level forum on sustainable development in July 2017 at the headquarters of UN in New York.
The UNDP intends to support the efforts of the Government and the Parliament of the Republic of Belarus in implementation of the Agenda 2030 and the SDGs.
The undisputable importance of cooperation between the Parliament of the Republic of Belarus and the United Nations Development Programme stems from the overall shared commitment to support the Parliament’s role in SDGs implementation.
UNDP signed the United Nations

1) Support to the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals, Council for Sustainable Development and Ministry of Foreign Affairs as their Secretariat is provided. 2) Informational support on SDGs is provided to the Parliament. 3) Exchange of expertise and best practices on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals through the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals, Council for Sustainable Development and Parliament is organized.

Output 1 Support to the National Coordinator on implementation of Sustainable Development Goals, Council for Sustainable Development and Ministry of Foreign Affairs as their Secretariat is provided. Output 2 Involvement of the Parliament in the issues of SDGs implementation is increased. Output 3 International cooperation in the context of SDGs implementation is enhanced.
